sections.heading: Set Phrases (決まり文句)
sections.content:
Set phrases (決まり文句 - kimari monku) are fixed expressions used in specific situations. These formulaic phrases are deeply ingrained in Japanese culture and using them correctly shows cultural awareness and social competence.

決まり文句 = Set phrase Expected in specific situations Not using them = unnatural Cultural markers Learn these as complete units

children.heading: Eating
children.content: Before eating: いただきます "I humbly receive" (this food) After eating: ごちそうさまでした "Thank you for the meal" Always say both Cultural ritual Shows appreciation Even when eating alone

children.heading: Leaving/Returning home
children.content: Leaving: 行ってきます "I'm going (and will return)" Response: 行ってらっしゃい "Go and come back safely" Returning: ただいま "I'm home" Response: おかえり(なさい) "Welcome back" Daily family ritual Expected exchanges Shows connection

children.heading: Beginning interaction
children.content: よろしくお願いします "Please treat me favorably" Used for: - First meetings - Asking favors - Starting work - General cooperation No direct English equivalent Extremely common Learn this first

children.heading: Email openings
children.content: お世話になっております "Thank you for your continued support" Standard business email opening Even first email Shows relationship Not literal translation Professional norm

children.heading: Phone
children.content: Answering: もしもし "Hello" (phone only) Business: お電話ありがとうございます "Thank you for calling" いつもお世話になっております "Thank you for your continued patronage" Phone-specific Never say もしもし in person

children.heading: During work
children.content: お疲れ様です "Thank you for your work" Use: - Passing colleagues - Throughout the day - Acknowledging effort Multipurpose Workplace standard Not used outside work

children.heading: Leaving work
children.content: お先に失礼します "Excuse me for leaving first" Response: お疲れ様でした "Good work today" Daily routine Respectful departure Shows consideration

children.heading: Entering home
children.content: お邪魔します "Excuse my intrusion" Literally: "I will be a bother" Always say this Shows humility Cultural expectation

children.heading: Leaving home
children.content: お邪魔しました "Thank you for having me" Past tense of entering phrase Shows gratitude Polite closure

children.heading: Making requests
children.content: すみませんが "Excuse me, but..." 恐れ入りますが "I'm sorry to trouble you, but..." お手数ですが "I know it's trouble, but..." Softening requests Showing consideration Cultural politeness

children.heading: Store greetings
children.content: Staff: いらっしゃいませ "Welcome" Customer: (no response needed) Staff when giving change: ありがとうございました "Thank you very much" Standard phrases Automatic Service industry ritual

children.heading: First meeting
children.content: 初めまして "Nice to meet you (first time)" [name]です "I'm [name]" よろしくお願いします "Please treat me well" Standard introduction sequence Always in this order Shows respect

children.heading: Long time no see
children.content: お久しぶりです "Long time no see" (polite) 久しぶり "Long time" (casual) ご無沙汰しております "I've been out of touch" (very formal) Acknowledging gap Reconnecting

children.heading: New Year
children.content: あけましておめでとうございます "Happy New Year" 今年もよろしくお願いします "Please treat me well this year too" Most important greeting First days of January Always say together

children.heading: Year end
children.content: 良いお年を "Have a good year" 今年もお世話になりました "Thank you for this year" December only Looking ahead Gratitude for year

children.heading: Standard openers
children.content: いい天気ですね "Nice weather, isn't it" 暑いですね / 寒いですね "It's hot/cold, isn't it" Weather = safe topic Social lubrication Expected small talk

children.heading: Acknowledgment
children.content: なるほど "I see / That makes sense" そうですね "That's right / I agree" 確かに "Certainly / Indeed" Showing you're listening Conversation lubricant

children.heading: Receiving compliments
children.content: いえいえ "No, no" (humble) そんなことないです "That's not true" まだまだです "I still have a long way to go" Cultural humility Deflecting praise Expected modesty

children.heading: Before asking
children.content: ちょっといいですか "Do you have a moment?" ちょっとお聞きしたいんですが "I'd like to ask something..." Softening approach Getting attention Polite introduction

children.heading: Supporting someone
children.content: 頑張って "Do your best / Good luck" ファイト "Fight!" (borrowed, encouragement) 応援してるよ "I'm cheering for you" Common encouragement Shows support

children.heading: To compliments
children.content: ありがとうございます "Thank you" But often followed by: でも... "But..." まだまだです "Not yet..." Accept but deflect Cultural norm Shows humility

children.heading: To offers
children.content: Accepting: お願いします "Please (I accept)" Declining: 大丈夫です "I'm okay (no thanks)" 結構です "I'm fine" (formal decline) Clear but polite

children.heading: Wrapping up
children.content: そろそろ "It's about time (to go)" そろそろ失礼します "I should be going now" またにしましょう "Let's do this again" Polite exit Not abrupt Social grace

children.heading: Why set phrases matter
children.content: Shows cultural competence Demonstrates respect Maintains social harmony Expected behavior Not using them: - Sounds unnatural - Seems rude - Shows ignorance Learn as complete units Don't translate literally Use in proper context

sections.heading: Common Mistakes
sections.content: ❌ Translating literally ✓ Learn as fixed expressions ❌ Skipping ritual phrases ✓ Always use them ❌ Using もしもし in person ✓ Phone only ❌ Not saying いただきます ✓ Before every meal These aren't optional Cultural expectations Master these first
